text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.

6M8English
from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we bring you a thoughtful topic and six items of vocabulary.
speaker: Neil

text: I'm Rob and I'm Neil.
And I'm Neil. So I was watching an old Woody Allen movie last night…
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, he's the anxious middle-aged guy from New York who talks about his problems all the time.
That's the one. He was paying for psychoanalysis.
And that's a type of talk therapy that was popular in the 1970s.
Do you know what therapy means, Rob?
Yes, therapy means a type of treatment for a problem or illness.
And talk therapy is a treatment for psychological problems,
which means problems of the mind, in case you were struggling with another long Greek word, Neil.
Train therapists work with you on ways to understand your thoughts, feelings and behaviour.
Hey, Rob, I'm an expert on long Greek words.
Psychology is the noun, by the way.
And the prefix psycho in front of any word means to do with the mind.
For example, the horror movie psycho,
For example the horror movie Psycho… which is all about the disturbed mind of the main character, Norman Bates…
speaker: Rob

text: Where disturbed means not thinking or behaving in a normal way,
because you have psychological problems,
Norman Bates would have found talk therapy helpful, don't you think?
Hmm, I'm not sure, really.
Anyway, let's have a quiz question, shall we now, Neil.
Can you tell me who invented the first talk therapy?
Was it a Boris Karloff, B Carl Jung, or C Sigmund Freud?
I'm going to go for Sigmund Freud.
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, interesting answer.
We'll find that later whether it was the right one or not.
Now, moving on, what do you think is the most common psychological problem to day, Neil?
It's depression.
And depression, a feeling of unhappiness that can affect
your thoughts, behavior and feelings,
is the most common psychological problem affecting people throughout the world.
Hmm, how depressing.
And that's the adjective.
How depressing! That's the adjective! It makes me feel depressed just thinking about it.
speaker: Rob

text: And depressed is the adjective we use to describe how we are feeling.
Don't feel depressed, Rob.
Let's listen to Professor Brent Roberts from the University of Illinois
to find out more about the benefits of talk therapy.
Seeing a therapist does result in marked changes in psychological functioning.
So, people get less depressed and they get less anxious.
And it seems to be regardless of what type of intervention is engaged.
And that is and has been one of the more positive aspects of the therapy research that we've seen.
So, when people talk to therapists about their problems,
it results in marked changes in their psychological functioning.
Marked here means obvious or noticeable.
And these marked changes are that people become less depressed and anxious!
speaker: Rob

text: An intervention, by the way, is something you do to improve a medical problem – and in this context, it refers to different types of talk therapy.
speaker: intervention

text: And in this context, it refers to different types of talk therapy.
But why is talking about our problems helpful, Neil?
speaker: Rob

text: I think it gives a shape to our problems.
It makes them seem clearer and that's a first step in being able to manage them.
Also, a problem shared is a problem halved as the saying goes.
There's also some scientific evidence that talk therapy can change the way we think and feel – by replacing negative thought patterns with positive ones.
speaker: Rob

text: by replacing negative thought patterns with positive ones.
Medication can also change the way we think and feel. Some people take pills to treat depression.
speaker: Neil

text: Some people take pills to treat depression.
But medication can have negative effects.
But medication can have negative effects, for example it can make you feel sleepy during the daytime.
speaker: Rob

text: Well, here's a positive thought.
Well, here's a positive thought – let's check how much we've learned today by going over today's vocabulary! We had therapy…
speaker: Neil

text: We had therapy.
Therapy is a type of treatment for a problem or illness. There's therapy – therapist – therapeutic.
speaker: Rob

text: There's therapy, therapist, therapeutic.
My therapist is using a new therapy with me – it's very therapeutic!
speaker: Neil

text: It's very therapeutic.
Therapotic means treating an illness.
But in a more general sense, it can simply mean relaxing.
For example, I find listening to music very therapeutic.
Okay, next up, psychological relating to the mind.
Psychology, psychologist, psychological.
Depression and anxiety are both psychological problems.
My friend is studying psychology at university.
speaker: Rob

text: I want to be a famous psychologist.
speaker: Neil

text: A career change at your age, Neil.
You've kept that one a secret.
Okay, number three, disturbed.
Not thinking or behaving in a normal way because you have psychological problems.
She was a disturbed young woman.
Or disturbing.
Or disturbing – I've been having very disturbing dreams recently.
speaker: Neil

text: No, Paul Neil.
Poor Neil! Disturbing here means 'upsetting or worrying'.
speaker: Rob

text: Next item, depression.
Next item – depression – a feeling of unhappiness that can affect your thoughts, behaviour, and feelings.
speaker: Neil

text: behavior and feelings.
We felt depressed by the news.
speaker: Rob

text: The news was very depressing!
speaker: Neil

text: All right, let's lift the mood.
Marked means obvious or noticeable.
There's been a marked improvement in your English homework.
There was a marked increase in the company's profits last year!
speaker: Neil

text: And finally, intervention.
Something you do to improve a problem,
medical or otherwise.
Let me intervene at this point.
Intervene, that's the verb and in this context, it means to interrupt.
And say, we've forgotten the quiz question, Rob.
Oh, no. Good intervention.
Yes, let's remind ourselves of that quiz question.
Who invented the first talking therapy?
And you said, Sigmund Freud, which is the right answer.
So well done, Neil.
Psychonalysis was invented in the early 1890s
by the Austrian-eurologist Sigmund Freud.
The patient lies on a couch and talks about their thoughts,
feelings and dreams while the therapist listens.
Psychoanalytic sessions typically last 50 minutes
and take place four to five times a week.
Okay, good to know.
But I think I prefer our own brand of talk therapy here on the show.
And listeners, you can express your thoughts and feelings
by visiting our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages.
Hmm, talk to you again soon.
Bye-bye.
So tell me about your childhood, Rob…
speaker: Neil

text: 6-minute English from the BBC.
